stories.text:
I don't mean improve the _experience_ that's been done to a fault already.. So much has been written about how to not-fix customers problems and have them walk away happy anyway.

It seems to have reached a breaking point, where a lot of companies and services simply has no capacity/ability/willingness to fix customer problems.

I speculate that economy of scale is somewhat to blame for this; After all, if you process hundreds of thousands of customers per day, it makes no difference if a a few edge-cases crashes and burns, it's simply not a good investment to fix them, because, unless they are extraordinarily famous (and probably not even then), no amount of noise they can make will actually impact your profits.

It seems that aside from the most absolutely trivial of problems, companies and services are entirely unwilling to fix it, that is, if they even have a human being that can be reached in the first place.

Is anyone working on finding the causes for this degeneration and identifying what can be done to rectify it?

I'm starting to develop the opinion that some law should be in place to enforce a level of customer-service from any company that operates for-profit.. probably even have some goverment instance to which one can file complaints with companies to get them to help you.
